QUALITY

Overall quality of offerings showed no change.




MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
  Page 2	 	Page 2


COMMENTS

Total Auction offerings were barely maintained and totalled 5.0 M/Kgs, of which the re-printed quantity comprised of 0.37 M/Kgs. Once again, there was good general demand in the backdrop of limited availability.

Ex-Estate offerings comprised of 0.65 M/Kgs. Overall quality of teas were reasonably well maintained, and witnessed strong demand and in general, a firm to dearer trend in prices.

Best Western BOP's were irregular following quality. Corresponding BOPF's - Select invoices gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and prices tend to fluctuate following quality. In the Below Best category, select clean leaf coloury BOP's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg. At the lower end, BOP's were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's - Better teas were barely steady, whilst the poorer sorts gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP's were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva BOP's - Select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer.

CTC teas continued to sell around last with no significant change in pricing.

Fair activity from shippers to the UK, Japan and China. Shippers to South Africa were somewhat selective, whilst shippers to the CIS continued to be active on a wide cross-section of the teas.

Low Growns totalled approximately 2.2 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.

In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, BOP1's in general were firm. High-priced OP1's were easier, whilst the balance appreciated. High-priced OPA's were irregular, whilst the balance together with the OP's were dearer. PEK/PEK1's, in general, appreciated.

In the Tippy catalogue, well-made FBOP/FF1's were easier, whilst the balance in general were firm.

In the Premium catalogue, a selection of Very Tippy teas sold around last levels, whilst the balance eased.




 

SRI LANKA TEA PRODUCTION - AUGUST 2025




 

AUGUST 2025/2024/2023

* Sri Lanka Tea Production for the month of August 2025 totalled 19.68 M/Kgs, witnessing a decline of 1.66 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.34 M/Kgs of August 2024. All elevations witnessed a decline, except for the Green Tea segment in comparison with the corresponding month of 2024.

* Compared to 18.36 M/Kgs of August 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows a gain of 1.32 M/Kgs (Refer table below).

JANUARY-AUGUST 2025/2024/2023

* January-August 2025 cumulative production totalled 176.82 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 4.34 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 172.48 M/Kgs of January-August 2024. All elevations recorded an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.

* Compared to 174.59 M/Kgs of January-August 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 2.23 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, all elevations except for the High Grown Elevation shows positive variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).

 

(Refer statistical details on Page No. 10)

MARKET



Good demand at enhanced rates


 
HIGH GROWN TEAS

BOP	

Best Western's were irregular following quality. In the Below Best category, select clean leaf coloury teas gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Plainer clean leaf types were Rs. 20 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were irregular. Uva's - Select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady.     



BOPF	

Best Western's - Select invoices gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and prices tend to fluctuate following quality. Teas in the Below Best category gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg. At the lower end, teas in the higher price bracket were barely steady, whilst the poorer sorts gained by up to Rs. 20-40 per kg. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. 



OP/OPA	

Well-made varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm on last levels.



PEKOE/PEKOE1	

Flavoury PEK/PEK1's and Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-50 per kg. PEK1's were firm to easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg. Select Best and Best Rotovane PEK's gained considerably following special inquiry, whilst the balance appreciated by Rs. 20-50 per kg. Below Best and poorer sorts had hardly any teas on offer.



FBOP/FBOPF1	

Flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were dearer by Rs. 50-100 per kg following quality, whilst the poorer sorts were difficult of sale. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's declined by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more at times, whilst the others and teas at the lower end were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

CROP AND WEATHER

For the period 09 - 16 September 2025




Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions

The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported bright weather and occasional evening showers throughout the week. Intermittent showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead, according to the Department of Meteorology. 

Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions

Both regions reported sunny weather throughout the week. Overcast conditions are expected in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions, in the week ahead. 

Low Growns

Bright weather was reported in the Low Grown Region throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead. 
 
Crop Intake

The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported an increase in the crop intake, whilst the Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions maintained.

MOMBASA AUCTION

SALE OF - 15TH AND 16TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)



There was good general demand for the 116,260 packages (7,847,712.00 kilos) on offer with 25.55% unsold.

MARKETS

Pakistan Packers were active with maintained support from Yemen, other Middle Eastern countries and Bazaar.  Kazakhstan and other CIS states were more selective while Afghanistan lent good but selective participation. Egyptian Packers were active with UK selective. Russia lent more selective interest with Sudan less active. There was some enquiry from South Sudan and Local Packers with Somalia remaining active at the lower end of the market.

BANGLADESH AUCTION

SALE OF - 15TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 19)



CTC LEAF: 59,549 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand.

BROKENS: Well made good liquoring Brokens met with a good demand and were mostly firm to occasionally dearer following competition. Medium varieties met with a fair demand and were about steady with some withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.

FANNINGS: Good liquoring Fannings met with a good demand and were mostly firm to slightly dearer following quality. Medium varieties met with a fair demand at around last levels with a few withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.
 
DUST: 12,788 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand. Well made good liquoring Dusts met with a good demand and sold at around last levels. Mediums were barely steady. Plain/BLF Dusts witnessed less demand with heavy withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.

COMMENTS: Market opened on a fairly good demand but gradually lessened with the progress of sale and witnessed little more withdrawals in the latter part. Blenders continued to lend good support for all varieties but Loose Tea buyers were selective. As a result, withdrawals were slightly higher this week.
Dusts sold well.

JAKARTA AUCTION

SALE OF - 12TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)



CTC LEAF

DEMAND: - Good Demand.

MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 88.G2% (12G8826.58kgs) of the total offering of 14444G1.2GKgs. Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.

BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.

ORTHODOX LEAF

DEMAND: - Good but selective demand.

MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.

BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Up country buyers lent useful support along with the internal buyers.

CTC DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 337373.57Kgs of which 2776G5.G6kgs were sold (82.31%). Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.

BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.

ORTHODOX DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. The secondary teas sold at irregularly easier prices. Other category primary C secondary dust sold substantially easier with some lots remaining un sold.

BUYING PATTERN: - Internal C regional packers were active. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.

    COMMENTS
Total Auction offerings were barely maintained and totalled 5.0 M/Kgs, of which the re-printed quantity comprised of 0.37 M/Kgs. Once again, there was good general demand in the backdrop of limited availability.
Ex-Estate offerings comprised of 0.65 M/Kgs. Overall quality of teas were reasonably well maintained, and witnessed strong demand and in general, a firm to dearer trend in prices.
Best Western BOP's were irregular following quality. Corresponding BOPF's - Select invoices gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and prices tend to fluctuate following quality. In the Below Best category, select clean leaf coloury BOP's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg. At the lower end, BOP's were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's - Better teas were barely steady, whilst the poorer sorts gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP's were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva BOP's - Select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer.
CTC teas continued to sell around last with no significant change in pricing.
Fair activity from shippers to the UK, Japan and China. Shippers to South Africa were somewhat selective, whilst shippers to the CIS continued to be active on a wide cross-section of the teas.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.2 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, BOP1's in general were firm. High-priced OP1's were easier, whilst the balance appreciated. High-priced OPA's were irregular, whilst the balance together with the OP's were dearer. PEK/PEK1's, in general, appreciated.
In the Tippy catalogue, well-made FBOP/FF1's were easier, whilst the balance in general were firm.
In the Premium catalogue, a selection of Very Tippy teas sold around last levels, whilst the balance eased.

 

SRI LANKA TEA PRODUCTION - AUGUST 2025

 
AUGUST 2025/2024/2023
* Sri Lanka Tea Production for the month of August 2025 totalled 19.68 M/Kgs, witnessing a decline of 1.66 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.34 M/Kgs of August 2024. All elevations witnessed a decline, except for the Green Tea segment in comparison with the corresponding month of 2024.
* Compared to 18.36 M/Kgs of August 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows a gain of 1.32 M/Kgs (Refer table below).

JANUARY-AUGUST 2025/2024/2023
* January-August 2025 cumulative production totalled 176.82 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 4.34 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 172.48 M/Kgs of January-August 2024. All elevations recorded an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.
* Compared to 174.59 M/Kgs of January-August 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 2.23 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, all elevations except for the High Grown Elevation shows positive variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).

 
(Refer statistical details on Page No. 10)  
  
World Tea News

* Compared to 18.36 M/Kgs of August 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows a gain of 1.32 M/Kgs (Refer table below).

JANUARY-AUGUST 2025/2024/2023
* January-August 2025 cumulative production totalled 176.82 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 4.34 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 172.48 M/Kgs of January-August 2024. All elevations recorded an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.
* Compared to 174.59 M/Kgs of January-August 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 2.23 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, all elevations except for the High Grown Elevation shows positive variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).

 
(Refer statistical details on Page No. 10)  
  
World Tea News
tables.text_content:
COMMENTS

Total Auction offerings were barely maintained and totalled 5.0 M/Kgs, of which the re-printed quantity comprised of 0.37 M/Kgs. Once again, there was good general demand in the backdrop of limited availability.

Ex-Estate offerings comprised of 0.65 M/Kgs. Overall quality of teas were reasonably well maintained, and witnessed strong demand and in general, a firm to dearer trend in prices.

Best Western BOP's were irregular following quality. Corresponding BOPF's - Select invoices gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and prices tend to fluctuate following quality. In the Below Best category, select clean leaf coloury BOP's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg. At the lower end, BOP's were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's - Better teas were barely steady, whilst the poorer sorts gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP's were irregular. Corresponding BOPF's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva BOP's - Select invoices were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Corresponding BOPF's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer.

CTC teas continued to sell around last with no significant change in pricing.

Fair activity from shippers to the UK, Japan and China. Shippers to South Africa were somewhat selective, whilst shippers to the CIS continued to be active on a wide cross-section of the teas.

Low Growns totalled approximately 2.2 M/Kgs. All categories met with fair demand.

In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, BOP1's in general were firm. High-priced OP1's were easier, whilst the balance appreciated. High-priced OPA's were irregular, whilst the balance together with the OP's were dearer. PEK/PEK1's, in general, appreciated.

In the Tippy catalogue, well-made FBOP/FF1's were easier, whilst the balance in general were firm.

In the Premium catalogue, a selection of Very Tippy teas sold around last levels, whilst the balance eased.




 

SRI LANKA TEA PRODUCTION - AUGUST 2025




 

AUGUST 2025/2024/2023

* Sri Lanka Tea Production for the month of August 2025 totalled 19.68 M/Kgs, witnessing a decline of 1.66 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.34 M/Kgs of August 2024. All elevations witnessed a decline, except for the Green Tea segment in comparison with the corresponding month of 2024.

* Compared to 18.36 M/Kgs of August 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows a gain of 1.32 M/Kgs (Refer table below).

JANUARY-AUGUST 2025/2024/2023

* January-August 2025 cumulative production totalled 176.82 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 4.34 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 172.48 M/Kgs of January-August 2024. All elevations recorded an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.

* Compared to 174.59 M/Kgs of January-August 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 2.23 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, all elevations except for the High Grown Elevation shows positive variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).

 

(Refer statistical details on Page No. 10) 

 
 

World Tea News

            Best Western's were irregular following quality. In the Below Best category, select clean leaf coloury teas gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Plainer clean leaf types were Rs. 20 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were irregular.             BOPF
            Best Western's - Select invoices gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg and more following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular and prices tend to fluctuate following quality. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer.  
        

        
        
            OP/OPA
            Well-made varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm on last levels.
        

        
        
            PEKOE/PEKOE1
            Flavoury PEK/PEK1's and Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-50 per kg. PEK1's were firm to easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg. Select Best and Best Rotovane PEK's gained considerably following special inquiry, whilst the balance appreciated by Rs. 20-50 per kg. Below Best and poorer sorts had hardly any teas on offer.
        

        
        
            FBOP/FBOPF1
            Flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were dearer by Rs. 50-100 per kg following quality, whilst the poorer sorts  were difficult of sale. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's declined by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more at times, whilst the others and teas at the lower end were firm to easier  by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

Teas in the Below Best category gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg. At the lower end, teas in the higher price bracket were barely steady, whilst the poorer sorts gained by up to Rs. 20-40 per kg. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's - Clean Small Leaf types were up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others were barely steady. Uva's were firm and Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer.
Well-made varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm on last levels.

Flavoury PEK/PEK1's and Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-50 per kg. PEK1's were firm to easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg. Select Best and Best Rotovane PEK's gained considerably following special inquiry, whilst the balance appreciated by Rs. 20-50 per kg. Below Best and poorer sorts had hardly any teas on offer.

Flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were dearer by Rs. 50-100 per kg following quality, whilst the poorer sorts  were difficult of sale. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's declined by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more at times, whilst the others and teas at the lower end were firm to easier  by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

 CROP AND WEATHER
  
   
    For the period 09 - 16 September 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya RegionsThe Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported bright weather and occasional evening showers throughout the week. Intermittent showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead, according to the Department of Meteorology. Uva/Uda Pussellawa RegionsBoth regions reported sunny weather throughout the week. Overcast conditions are expected in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions, in the week ahead. Low GrownsBright weather was reported in the Low Grown Region throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead.  Crop IntakeThe Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported an increase in the crop intake, whilst the Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions maintained.

CROP AND WEATHER

For the period 09 - 16 September 2025




Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions

The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported bright weather and occasional evening showers throughout the week. Intermittent showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead, according to the Department of Meteorology. 

Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions

Both regions reported sunny weather throughout the week. Overcast conditions are expected in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions, in the week ahead. 

Low Growns

Bright weather was reported in the Low Grown Region throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead. 
 
Crop Intake

The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported an increase in the crop intake, whilst the Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions maintained.

            There was good general demand for the 116,260 packages (7,847,712.00 kilos) on offer with 25.55% unsold.MARKETSPakistan Packers were active with maintained support from Yemen, other Middle Eastern countries and Bazaar.  Kazakhstan and other CIS states were more selective while Afghanistan lent good but selective participation. Egyptian Packers were active with UK selective. Russia lent more selective interest with Sudan less active. There was some enquiry from South Sudan and Local Packers with Somalia remaining active at the lower end of the market. OFFERINGSLeaf Grades                    -    56,720 packages (3,717,540.00 kilos) - 22.99% unsold.Dust Grades                   -    46,000 packages (3,428,858.00 kilos) - 33.74% unsold.Secondary Grades          -    13,540 packages (   701,314.00 kilos) - 8.42% unsold.LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)BP1:Best - Irregular interest and varied between USC20 above previous rates to easier by up to USC28.       Brighter - Met irregular enquiry ranging between USC17 dearer to easier by up to USC14.   Mediums - KTDA mediums were more irregular varying between USC5 dearer to easier by up to USC20. Plantation mediums gained up to USC5 but some lines were up to USC4 below previous rates.  Lower Medium - Irregular and lost up to USC9 with select teas steady to USC10 dearer.  Plainer - Firm to USC3 dearer to easier by up to USC6.  PF1:Best - Were mostly dearer by up to USC20 but select invoices irregularly shed up to USC17.    Brighter - Saw strong support and varied between firm to USC22 above previous levels to easier by up to USC17.     Mediums - KTDA mediums mostly appreciated by up to USC20 with select teas USC8 below previous levels. Plantation mediums lost up to USC10 but some lines held firm to USC5 above last rates.  Lower Medium - Ranged between steady to USC6 dearer to mostly easier by up to USC8.  Plainer - Mostly gained by up to USC8 but few select invoices lost up to USC5.

            SALE OF - 15TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 19)
        
    
    

    
        
            CTC LEAF: 59,549 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand.BROKENS: Well made good liquoring Brokens met with a good demand and were mostly firm to occasionally dearer following competition. Medium varieties met with a fair demand and were about steady with some withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.FANNINGS: Good liquoring Fannings met with a good demand and were mostly firm to slightly dearer following quality. Medium varieties met with a fair demand at around last levels with a few withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals. DUST: 12,788 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand. Well made good liquoring Dusts met with a good demand and sold at around last levels. Mediums were barely steady. Plain/BLF Dusts witnessed less demand with heavy withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.COMMENTS: Market opened on a fairly good demand but gradually lessened with the progress of sale and witnessed little more withdrawals in the latter part. Blenders continued to lend good support for all varieties but Loose Tea buyers were selective. As a result, withdrawals were slightly higher this week.Dusts sold well.Our Catalogue: (Sale 19) Avg : Tk 248.14, Sold 75.17% , (Sale 18) Avg : Tk 247.96, Sold 58.15%

            JAKARTA AUCTION
        
        
            SALE OF - 12TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)
        
    
    

    
        
            CTC LEAFDEMAND: - Good Demand.MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 88.G2% (12G8826.58kgs) of the total offering of 14444G1.2GKgs. Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.ORTHODOX LEAFDEMAND: - Good but selective demand.MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Up country buyers lent useful support along with the internal buyers.CTC DUSTDEMAND: - Good demand.MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 337373.57Kgs of which 2776G5.G6kgs were sold (82.31%). Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.ORTHODOX DUSTDEMAND: - Good demand.MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. The secondary teas sold at irregularly easier prices. Other category primary C secondary dust sold substantially easier with some lots remaining un sold.BUYING PATTERN: - Internal C regional packers were active. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd

JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 12TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)
CTC LEAFDEMAND: - Good Demand.MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 88.G2% (12G8826.58kgs) of the total offering of 14444G1.2GKgs. Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.ORTHODOX LEAFDEMAND: - Good but selective demand.MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Up country buyers lent useful support along with the internal buyers.CTC DUSTDEMAND: - Good demand.MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 337373.57Kgs of which 2776G5.G6kgs were sold (82.31%). Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.ORTHODOX DUSTDEMAND: - Good demand.MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. The secondary teas sold at irregularly easier prices. Other category primary C secondary dust sold substantially easier with some lots remaining un sold.BUYING PATTERN: - Internal C regional packers were active. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 15TH AND 16TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)
There was good general demand for the 116,260 packages (7,847,712.00 kilos) on offer with 25.55% unsold.MARKETSPakistan Packers were active with maintained support from Yemen, other Middle Eastern countries and Bazaar.  Kazakhstan and other CIS states were more selective while Afghanistan lent good but selective participation. Egyptian Packers were active with UK selective. Russia lent more selective interest with Sudan less active. There was some enquiry from South Sudan and Local Packers with Somalia remaining active at the lower end of the market. OFFERINGSLeaf Grades                    -    56,720 packages (3,717,540.00 kilos) - 22.99% unsold.Dust Grades                   -    46,000 packages (3,428,858.00 kilos) - 33.74% unsold.Secondary Grades          -    13,540 packages (   701,314.00 kilos) - 8.42% unsold.LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)BP1:Best - Irregular interest and varied between USC20 above previous rates to easier by up to USC28.       Brighter - Met irregular enquiry ranging between USC17 dearer to easier by up to USC14.   Mediums - KTDA mediums were more irregular varying between USC5 dearer to easier by up to USC20. Plantation mediums gained up to USC5 but some lines were up to USC4 below previous rates.  Lower Medium - Irregular and lost up to USC9 with select teas steady to USC10 dearer.  Plainer - Firm to USC3 dearer to easier by up to USC6.  PF1:Best - Were mostly dearer by up to USC20 but select invoices irregularly shed up to USC17.    Brighter - Saw strong support and varied between firm to USC22 above previous levels to easier by up to USC17.     Mediums - KTDA mediums mostly appreciated by up to USC20 with select teas USC8 below previous levels. Plantation mediums lost up to USC10 but some lines held firm to USC5 above last rates.  Lower Medium - Ranged between steady to USC6 dearer to mostly easier by up to USC8.  Plainer - Mostly gained by up to USC8 but few select invoices lost up to USC5.

There was good general demand for the 116,260 packages (7,847,712.00 kilos) on offer with 25.55% unsold.

MARKETS

Pakistan Packers were active with maintained support from Yemen, other Middle Eastern countries and Bazaar.  Kazakhstan and other CIS states were more selective while Afghanistan lent good but selective participation. Egyptian Packers were active with UK selective. Russia lent more selective interest with Sudan less active. There was some enquiry from South Sudan and Local Packers with Somalia remaining active at the lower end of the market.

OFFERINGS

Leaf Grades                    -    56,720 packages (3,717,540.00 kilos) - 22.99% unsold.
Dust Grades                   -    46,000 packages (3,428,858.00 kilos) - 33.74% unsold.
Secondary Grades          -    13,540 packages (   701,314.00 kilos) - 8.42% unsold.

LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)

BP1:

Best - Irregular interest and varied between USC20 above previous rates to easier by up to USC28.       
Brighter - Met irregular enquiry ranging between USC17 dearer to easier by up to USC14.   
Mediums - KTDA mediums were more irregular varying between USC5 dearer to easier by up to USC20. Plantation mediums gained up to USC5 but some lines were up to USC4 below previous rates.  
Lower Medium - Irregular and lost up to USC9 with select teas steady to USC10 dearer.  
Plainer - Firm to USC3 dearer to easier by up to USC6.  

PF1:

Best - Were mostly dearer by up to USC20 but select invoices irregularly shed up to USC17.    
Brighter - Saw strong support and varied between firm to USC22 above previous levels to easier by up to USC17.     
Mediums - KTDA mediums mostly appreciated by up to USC20 with select teas USC8 below previous levels. Plantation mediums lost up to USC10 but some lines held firm to USC5 above last rates.  
Lower Medium - Ranged between steady to USC6 dearer to mostly easier by up to USC8.  
Plainer - Mostly gained by up to USC8 but few select invoices lost up to USC5.

BANGLADESH AUCTION

SALE OF - 15TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 19)



CTC LEAF: 59,549 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand.

BROKENS: Well made good liquoring Brokens met with a good demand and were mostly firm to occasionally dearer following competition. Medium varieties met with a fair demand and were about steady with some withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.

FANNINGS: Good liquoring Fannings met with a good demand and were mostly firm to slightly dearer following quality. Medium varieties met with a fair demand at around last levels with a few withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.
 
DUST: 12,788 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand. Well made good liquoring Dusts met with a good demand and sold at around last levels. Mediums were barely steady. Plain/BLF Dusts witnessed less demand with heavy withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.

COMMENTS: Market opened on a fairly good demand but gradually lessened with the progress of sale and witnessed little more withdrawals in the latter part. Blenders continued to lend good support for all varieties but Loose Tea buyers were selective. As a result, withdrawals were slightly higher this week.
Dusts sold well.

Our Catalogue: (Sale 19) Avg : Tk 248.14, Sold 75.17% , (Sale 18) Avg : Tk 247.96, Sold 58.15%

JAKARTA AUCTION

SALE OF - 12TH SEPTEMBER 2025 (SALE NO. 37)



CTC LEAF

DEMAND: - Good Demand.

MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 88.G2% (12G8826.58kgs) of the total offering of 14444G1.2GKgs. Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.

BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.

ORTHODOX LEAF

DEMAND: - Good but selective demand.

MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.

BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Up country buyers lent useful support along with the internal buyers.

CTC DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 337373.57Kgs of which 2776G5.G6kgs were sold (82.31%). Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.

BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.

ORTHODOX DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. The secondary teas sold at irregularly easier prices. Other category primary C secondary dust sold substantially easier with some lots remaining un sold.

BUYING PATTERN: - Internal C regional packers were active. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.


Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd

tables.text_content:
CTC LEAF: 59,549 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand.

BROKENS: Well made good liquoring Brokens met with a good demand and were mostly firm to occasionally dearer following competition. Medium varieties met with a fair demand and were about steady with some withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.

FANNINGS: Good liquoring Fannings met with a good demand and were mostly firm to slightly dearer following quality. Medium varieties met with a fair demand at around last levels with a few withdrawals. Plainer varieties met with less demand at around last levels and witnessed more withdrawals. BLF teas met with a fairly good market at around last levels with a few withdrawals.
 
DUST: 12,788 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand. Well made good liquoring Dusts met with a good demand and sold at around last levels. Mediums were barely steady. Plain/BLF Dusts witnessed less demand with heavy withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.

COMMENTS: Market opened on a fairly good demand but gradually lessened with the progress of sale and witnessed little more withdrawals in the latter part. Blenders continued to lend good support for all varieties but Loose Tea buyers were selective. As a result, withdrawals were slightly higher this week.
Dusts sold well.

Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.ORTHODOX LEAFDEMAND: - Good but selective demand.MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.ORTHODOX DUSTDEMAND: - Good demand.MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.

tables.text_content:
CTC LEAF

DEMAND: - Good Demand.

MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 88.G2% (12G8826.58kgs) of the total offering of 14444G1.2GKgs. Best category teas sold at irregular prices following quality. Good category teas saw a slight improvement in demand and prices were irregular in line with quality. Better medium larger broken sold barely steady whilst the other sorts sold dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 4 or more, especially on the smaller broken. Fanning grade continued with good demand but at slightly lower levels compared to last. Medium C plainer sorts sold at steady levels except for the cleaner, blacker sorts which saw a slight increment in prices.

BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders were active and absorbed as much as 4G.72% of the total CTC leaf sold. Up country buyers were fairly active along with the regional packers on the best C good teas. The other internal and local buyers were fairly selective on their purchases. CIS, Russia and the middle east buyers continued to be active.

ORTHODOX LEAF

DEMAND: - Good but selective demand.

MARKET: - The high grown well-made blacker whole leaf grades sold firm to dearer following quality. Other category whole leaf grades were steady. Broken C fanning grades sold at barely steady levels.

BUYING PATTERN: - CIS C middle east exporters were active. Up country buyers lent useful support along with the internal buyers.

CTC DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 337373.57Kgs of which 2776G5.G6kgs were sold (82.31%). Limited volume of best category teas sold irregularly dearer following quality. Good category dust sold firm to dearer in the price range of Rs 2 to 10 or more. The better medium category dusts were dearer by Rs 4 to 5 and sometimes more on competition particularly on blacker and finer sorts. Medium C plainer sorts sold dearer by Rs 2-4.

BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. The up-country buyers were active along with regional and local packers. Exporters continued to operate actively, particularly on the blacker finer dust.

ORTHODOX DUST

DEMAND: - Good demand.

MARKET: - High grown primary sold substantially dearer following quality and competition. The secondary teas sold at irregularly easier prices. Other category primary C secondary dust sold substantially easier with some lots remaining un sold.

BUYING PATTERN: - Internal C regional packers were active. Exporters were fairly active on the secondary dust.


Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd

tables.text_content:
Final Market Report

Market: CTC
There was good demand for the good and best Assams at steady to occasionally dearer rates following competition . Remainder witnessed fair demand at easier levels and with noticeable withdrawals, particularly brownish/ fibrous and plainer sorts.

Buying Pattern: CTC.
There was fair support from HUL, Western India buyers. TCPL, North India, other packeteers operated. Export enquiry was seen on the larger brokens.

Market: DUST
The dust market followed a trend similar to the leaf market.

Buying Pattern: DUST
HUL was active on the better liquoring sorts. TCPL, Western India, other packeteers operated.

Courtesy - ASSOCIATED BROKERS PVT. LTD
